items.description: Bruce's C compiler is a simple C compiler that produces 8086 assembler for tiny/small memory models.
items.title: bcc - Bruce's C Compiler

items.description: DJ Delorie's complete 32-bit C/C++ development environment for Intel 80386. Used for Quake.
items.title: DJGPP

items.description: A 16-bit counterpart to DJGPP, a GCC-based toolchain for developing 16-bit (8086 to 80286, a.k.a. IA-16) DOS applications, currently maintained by TK Chia.
items.title: GCC IA-16 toolchain

items.description: Very small debugger for real-mode DOS programs with Borland's Turbo like UI. Features an i80486 disassembler, and i8086 assembler.
items.title: Insight

children.description: The  is very valuable in order to understand working with both version 1.9 and the V2 fork.
children.title: documentation

items.description:
Formerly commercial C/C++ development environment for 16- and 32-bit DOS and
Windows. The current official version is 1.9. A GitHub fork is also available. Used for Doom I-II, Warcraft I-II, Duke Nukem 3D, Full Throttle, Dark Forces and Retro City Rampage.
items.title: Open Watcom

items.description:
GitHub fork which is actively maintained and is
ported to 64-bit Windows and Linux.
items.title: Open Watcom V2

items.description: C IDE and compiler from Borland first released in 1987.
items.title: Turbo C 2.01

items.description: C++ IDE and compiler from Borland released in 1991.
items.title: Turbo C++ 1.01

items.description: C++ IDE and compiler from Borland released in 1992.
items.title: Turbo C++ 3.0

items.description: IDE to develop DOS games in 2d, mode 7 and 3d. Released in 1998.
items.title: DIV Games Studio 2

items.description: A small, portable, procedural, block-structured, recursive, almost typeless, and to some degree object-oriented programming language by Nils M. Holm.
items.title: T3X

items.description: Portable self-hosting C compiler capable of producing executables for a number of platforms, including real and protected mode DOS programs, by Alexei A. Frounze.
items.title: SmallerC

items.description: A self-hosting Small-C Compiler Toolkit for DOS(8086) with: K&R C Compiler, Make, Linker, Assembler. First released in 1982 by Jim E. Hendrix.
items.title: Small-C Toolkit

items.description: JavaScript programming environment for MS-DOS, FreeDOS or any DOS-based Windows (like 95, 98, ME).
items.title: DOjS

items.description: Online demo of Lua 5.3.5, compiled for MS-DOS on the Intel 80486 processor.
items.title: Lua for DOS

items.description: FreeDOS ad-hoc module for .
items.title: Micropython for FreeDOS

items.description: Perl for DOS.
items.title: perldos

items.description: Python for DOS, including multi-threading, networking and OpenGL.
items.title: PythonD
Scripting languages and interpreters for DOS

items.description: Game development library for DOS, Windows and Linux. 4.2 version supports DOS platform.
items.title: Allegro 4.2

items.description: A framework for making 2D DOS games in Lua. API based on a subset of the LÃ–VE API.
items.title: LoveDOS

items.description: Marco A. Marrero's DOS VGA/hardware library implemented in assembly and Turbo Pascal.
items.title: DOS-VGA-Game

items.description: Original source code for the DIGPAK sound drivers uploaded to GitHub by John W. Ratcliff.
items.title: DIGPAK sound drivers source code

items.description: List of all homebrew DOS games: http://www.doshaven.eu
Christopher Wellons's x86 real mode DOS Asteroids clone created as an entry for Lundum Dare #31.
items.title: DOS Defender

items.description: First-person 2.5D dungeon-crawler on protected mode. Written in C++, includes software rendering, fixed point math, test coverage and sound (PC speaker, Adlib, OPL2LPT).
items.title: Dungeons of Noudar

items.description: Pong clone for DOS, Windows and Linux. Uses PC speaker for sound on DOS.
items.title: Emeritus Pong

items.description: Flappy Bird clone written in 16 bit assembly. Not a DOS program, but a PC-Booter application instead (although it's also possible to build a COM executable for DOS).
items.title: Floppy Bird

items.description: Turbo Pascal with few games in C and C++. Games include Nibbles, Connect Four, Ms Pacman clone and two arcade/platform games. One of them (ra2) was written using Allegro. Utilities are all written in Turbo Pascal, these include game system routines, file and disk utilities and terminate-and-stay-resident programs (TSR).
items.title: George M. Tzoumas's collection of MS-DOS games and utilities

items.description: Platformer written in C using DJGPP.
items.title: Gold Mine Run!

items.description: 80s style arcade shooter written in Quickbasic. Also the very first known DOS game that supports Oculus Rift VR headset.
items.title: Gridfighter 3D

items.description: Hangman clone written in Basic. Runs on at least 80286 processors and uses EGA graphics.
items.title: Hangman

items.description: 3D maze game using CGA graphics with algebra as theme.
items.title: Magenta's Maze

items.description: Super Mario Bros clone written in Turbo Pascal.
items.title: Mario

items.description: Descendant of the original  rougelike game first released in 1987 available on multiple platforms.
items.title: NetHack

items.description: Gomoku clone written in C. Works on DOS, ZX Spectrum, ZX81, ZX80, APPLE1, AS400 and Windows.
items.title: Piskworks

items.description: Overhead puzzle game written in C. Web version uses  to embed DOSBox into HTML5. However, the original executable is also downloadable and buildable with Open Watcom.
items.title: Plutonium Caverns

items.description: Tetris clone written in C. Runs on DOS, Unix/Linux, ZX Spectrum and Windows.
items.title: Ptakovina

items.description: Sudoku clone written in C. Runs on 8086/8088 CPU, uses CGA, MCGA or VGA graphics and uses a mouse.
items.title: sudoku86

items.description: Tetris clone written in assembly.
items.title: Tetris

items.description: puzzle game written in Turbo Pascal. Originally released in 1996.
items.title: Towers of Hanoi

items.description: Text-mode Pong clone written in C. Runs as PC-Booter game and under DOS.
items.title: x86 pong

items.description: Text-mode Snake clone written in C. Runs on 8086 DOS.
items.title: zmiy
Homebrew games with source code

items.description: Sci-fi side-scrolling platform game. Regarded as an innovative cult classic by most people. Supports SVGA mode up to 1280x1024 resolution. Written in C, the architecture includes a Lisp-scripting engine.
items.title: Abuse

items.description: Point-and-click adventure game set in a dystopian future. Written in assembly.
items.title: Beneath a Steel Sky

items.description: 2D top-down shooter developed by Softdisk (later becoming id Software). Supports EGA and CGA graphics. Written in Turbo Pascal and assembly.
items.title: Catacomb

items.description: First-person shooter in fantasy setting developed by Softdisk (later becoming id Software). Features pseudo-3D graphics with raycasting technique. Supports EGA graphics. Written in C and assembly. Compiled with Borland C++ 3.1.
items.title: Catacomb 3D

items.description: Side-scrolling platform game developed by id Software. Keen Dreams is the Commander Keen game created between Keen 3 and Keen 4 (often considered "Keen 3.5"), but was not widely released. Written in C and assembly.
items.title: Commander Keen in Keen Dreams

items.description: First sci-fi FPS/space shooter to feature entirely true 3D graphics. Written in C and assembly.
items.title: Descent

items.description: Sequel to Descent. Written in C and assembly.
items.title: Descent II

items.description: Sci-fi FPS developed by id Software where you fight demons from hell on Mars. The DOS-specific code for Doom could not be published because of a dependency to the licensed DMX sound library, hence why it's cleaned up and only the Linux source is there. However, the Heretic and Hexen projects contain the original DOS code in a way where DMX-related code is removed.
items.title: Doom

items.description: FPS developed by Apogee featuring the iconic character Duke Nukem. Written in C. Compiled with Watcom C/C++ 10.0.
items.title: Duke Nukem 3D

items.description: Dark fantasy FPS running on id Software's Doom engine.
items.title: Heretic

items.description: Indirect sequel to Heretic.
items.title: Hexen: Beyond Heretic

items.description: FPS developed by id Software. Features pseudo-3D graphics with raycasting technique, before Catacomb 3D and Wolfeinstein 3D. Written in C and assembly.
items.title: Hovertank 3D

items.description: FPS developed by id Software set in a fully 3D world. Written in C. Compiled with DJGPP for DOS.
items.title: Quake

items.description: FPS developed by Apogee. It was developed as a follow-up to Wolfenstein 3D, but was altered and became a standalone game instead. Uses a heavily modified Wolfenstein 3D engine. Written in C.
items.title: Rise of the Triad: Dark War

items.description: Side-scrolling shoot 'em up created by David L. Clark in 1984. The game involves piloting a Sopwith biplane, attempting to bomb enemy buildings while avoiding fire from enemy planes and various other obstacles.
items.title: Sopwith

items.description: FPS developed by id Software set in the Nazi German prison Castle Wolfenstein. Features pseudo-3D graphics with raycasting technique. Written in C and assembly.
items.title: Wolfenstein 3D
Commercial games with published source code

items.description: A TSR that emulates Sound Blaster and OPL3 in pure DOS using modern PCI-based (onboard and add-in card) sound cards. Supports both real mode and protected mode games!
items.title: SBEMU

items.description: A fork of SBEMU (see above), which also aims to offer Sound Blaster emulation for modern PC hardware, in both real mode and protected mode games.
items.title: VSB
